headline: One Bowl Chocolate Cake
description: This simple one bowl chocolate cake has a rich and moist texture and takes only minutes to prepare. Frost with your favorite chocolate frosting.

video.description: No need to reach for a box cake mix anymore when there's a super-easy, no-fuss, no-baking-skills-required rich, and chocolatey chocolate cake that you can absolutely bake from scratch.

name: One Bowl Chocolate Cake

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour two nine inch round pans.
In a large bowl, stir together the sugar, flour, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda and salt.
Add the eggs, milk, oil and vanilla, mix for 2 minutes on medium speed of mixer.
Stir in the boiling water last. Batter will be thin.
Pour evenly into the prepared pans.
Bake 30 to 35 minutes in the preheated oven, until the cake tests done with a toothpick. Cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then remove to a wire rack to cool completely.

SEE A REVISION OF THIS REVIEW BELOW: I really liked this simple recipe. In fact, it gave me renewed hope in cakes, because fundamentally, I'm just not a "cake" guy. I'm 70+ years old now, and throughout my life, dating back to the early 50s, the women in the family always made pies (not cakes), and if you asked the men, they'd all say, it's because cakes are just too dry! Not this one! This recipe yields a nice, not too dense, flavorful and moist cake. The problem is, like nearly ALL cake recipes that I've encountered over the years that utilize oil of any kind (corn oil, vegetable oil, etc.), they sag or collapse in the very middle, no matter how small a pan you use, and this even includes things like cornbread. Sag, sag, sag! This is a "fatal" flaw in my view, as it causes a 1/2"-3/4" deep crater in the middle of each 9" round cake, that ends up pooling the icing, and I have not yet found a way to resolve it. Very frustrating! Otherwise, this is a fantastic and simple recipe. And let me be both fair and clear . . . I do not believe the sagging issue to be related solely to the oil or to this recipe or others. I think it's more a matter of elevation, oven temp, excess baking soda/powder or other things known to cause such sagging. REVISED: 01/20/2023 I tried this simple recipe again yesterday and it turned-out "flawless"! Absolutely flawless texture, moisture and flavor. I followed the recipe precisely, other than increasing the cocoa to one full cup, and baking at 360-degrees for 32-minutes (instead of the 350-degrees called-for by recipe). I greased and floured both pans, followed by parchment paper, then a light coat of PAM spray, and there was no sticking to either pan. The only change that I plan on trying in the near future is adjusting the total quantity of the final mixture. This most recent attempt led to two 9" round cakes that were each only about 1.5-2.0" tall in the finished pans, making the final (iced) cake height only about 4.5" high. I would like to increase this height to 5.0-5.5", without doing a third cake, so I'm going to try multiplying the quantities or volumes of all components by a factor of 1/4 (0.25).
